title: Proposition 1
prose:
Similar polygons (inscribed) in circles are to one another as the squares on the diameters (of the circles).

Let {ABC circle X} and {FGH circle Y} be circles, and let {ABCDE polygon} and {FGHKL polygon} be similar polygons (inscribed) in them (respectively), and let {BM line} and {GN line} be the diameters of the circles (respectively).
I say that as the square on {BM line} is to the square on {GN line}, so polygon {ABCDE polygon} (is) to polygon {FGHKL polygon}.

For let {BE line}, {AM line}, {GL line}, and {FN line} have been joined.
And since polygon {ABCDE polygon} (is) similar to polygon {FGHKL polygon}, angle {BAE angle} is also equal to (angle) {GFL angle}, and as {BA line} is to {AE line}, so {GF line} (is) to {FL line} [Def. 6.1].
So, {BAE polygon} and {GFL polygon} are two triangles having one angle equal to one angle, (namely), {BAE angle} (equal) to {GFL angle}, and the sides around the equal angles proportional.
Triangle {ABE polygon} is thus equiangular with triangle {FGL polygon} [Prop. 6.6].
Thus, angle {AEB angle} is equal to (angle) {FLG angle}.
But, {AEB angle} is equal to {AMB angle}, and {FLG angle} to {FNG angle}, for they stand on the same circumference [Prop. 3.27].
Thus, {AMB angle} is also equal to {FNG angle}.
And the right-angle {BAM angle} is also equal to the right-angle {GFN angle} [Prop. 3.31].
Thus, the remaining (angle) is also equal to the remaining (angle) [Prop. 1.32].
Thus, triangle {ABM polygon} is equiangular with triangle {FGN polygon}.
Thus, proportionally, as {BM line} is to {GN line}, so {BA line} (is) to {GF line} [Prop. 6.4].
But, the (ratio) of the square on {BM line} to the square on {GN line} is the square of the ratio of {BM line} to {GN line}, and the (ratio) of polygon {ABCDE polygon} to polygon {FGHKL polygon} is the square of the (ratio) of {BA line} to {GF line} [Prop. 6.20].
And, thus, as the square on {BM line} (is) to the square on {GN line}, so polygon {ABCDE polygon} (is) to polygon {FGHKL polygon}.

Thus, similar polygons (inscribed) in circles are to one another as the squares on the diameters (of the circles).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 2
prose:
Circles are to one another as the squares on (their) diameters.

Let {ABCD circle X} and {EFGH circle Y} be circles, and [let] {BD line} and {FH line} [be] their diameters.
I say that as circle {ABCD circle X} is to circle {EFGH circle Y}, so the square on {BD line} (is) to the square on {FH line}.

For if the circle {ABCD circle X} is not to the (circle) {EFGH circle Y}, as the square on {BD line} (is) to the (square) on {FH line}, then as the (square) on {BD line} (is) to the (square) on {FH line}, so circle {ABCD circle X} will be to some area either less than, or greater than, circle {EFGH circle Y}.
Let it, first of all, be (in that ratio) to (some) lesser (area), {S given}.
And let the square {EFGH polygon} have been inscribed in circle {EFGH circle Y} [Prop. 4.6].
So the inscribed square is greater than half of circle {EFGH circle Y}, inasmuch as if we draw tangents to the circle through the points {E point}, {F point}, {G point}, and {H point}, then square {EFGH polygon} is half of the square circumscribed about the circle [Prop. 1.47], and the circle is less than the circumscribed square.
Hence, the inscribed square {EFGH polygon} is greater than half of circle {EFGH circle Y}.
Let the circumferences {EF arcc Y}, {FG arcc Y}, {GH arcc Y}, and {HE arcc Y} have been cut in half at points {K point}, {L point}, {M point}, and {N point} (respectively), and let {EK line}, {KF line}, {FL line}, {LG line}, {GM line}, {MH line}, {HN line}, and {NE line} have been joined.
And, thus, each of the triangles {EKF polygon}, {FLG polygon}, {GMH polygon}, and {HNE polygon} is greater than half of the segment of the circle about it, inasmuch as if we draw tangents to the circle through points {K point}, {L point}, {M point}, and {N point}, and complete the parallelograms on the straight-lines {EF line}, {FG line}, {GH line}, and {HE line}, then each of the triangles {EKF polygon}, {FLG polygon}, {GMH polygon}, and {HNE polygon} will be half of the parallelogram about it, but the segment about it is less than the parallelogram.
Hence, each of the triangles {EKF polygon}, {FLG polygon}, {GMH polygon}, and {HNE polygon} is greater than half of the segment of the circle about it.
So, by cutting the circumferences remaining behind in half, and joining straight-lines, and doing this continually, we will (eventually) leave behind some segments of the circle whose (sum) will be less than the excess by which circle {EFGH circle Y} exceeds the area {S given}.
For we showed in the first theorem of the tenth book that if two unequal magnitudes are laid out, and if (a part) greater than a half is subtracted from the greater, and (if from) the remainder (a part) greater than a half (is subtracted), and this happens continually, then some magnitude will (eventually) be left which will be less than the lesser laid out magnitude [Prop. 10.1].
Therefore, let the (segments) have been left, and let the (sum of the) segments of the circle {EFGH circle Y} on {EK arcc Y}, {KF arcc Y}, {FL arcc Y}, {LG arcc Y}, {GM arcc Y}, {MH arcc Y}, {HN arcc Y}, and {NE arcc Y} be less than the excess by which circle {EFGH circle Y} exceeds area {S given}.
Thus, the remaining polygon {EKFLGMHN polygon} is greater than area {S given}.
And let the polygon {AOBPCQDR polygon}, similar to the polygon {EKFLGMHN polygon}, have been inscribed in circle {ABCD circle X}.
Thus, as the square on {BD line} is to the square on {FH line}, so polygon {AOBPCQDR polygon} (is) to polygon {EKFLGMHN polygon} [Prop. 12.1].
But, also, as the square on {BD line} (is) to the square on {FH line}, so circle {ABCD circle X} (is) to area {S given}.
And, thus, as circle {ABCD circle X} (is) to area {S given}, so polygon {AOBPCQDR polygon} (is) to polygon {EKFLGMHN polygon} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, alternately, as circle {ABCD circle X} (is) to the polygon (inscribed) within it, so area {S given} (is) to polygon {EKFLGMHN polygon} [Prop. 5.16].
And circle {ABCD circle X} (is) greater than the polygon (inscribed) within it.
Thus, area {S given} is also greater than polygon {EKFLGMHN polygon}.
But, (it is) also less.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, the square on {BD line} is not to the (square) on {FH line}, as circle {ABCD circle X} (is) to some area less than circle {EFGH circle Y}.
So,similarly,wecan show that the (square) on {FH line} (is) not to the (square) on {BD line} as circle {EFGH circle Y} (is) to some area less than circle {ABCD circle X} either.

So, I say that neither (is) the (square) on {BD line} to the (square) on {FH line}, as circle {ABCD circle X} (is) to some area greater than circle {EFGH circle Y}.

For, if possible, let it be (in that ratio) to (some) greater (area), {S given}.
Thus, inversely, as the square on {FH line} [is] to the (square) on {DB line}, so area {S given} (is) to circle {ABCD circle X} [Prop. 5.7 corr.].
But, as area {S given} (is) to circle {ABCD circle X}, so circle {EFGH circle Y} (is) to some area less than circle {ABCD circle X} (see lemma).
And, thus, as the (square) on {FH line} (is) to the (square) on {BD line}, so circle {EFGH circle Y} (is) to some area less than circle {ABCD circle X} [Prop. 5.11].
The very thing was shown (to be) impossible.
Thus, as the square on {BD line} is to the (square) on {FH line}, so circle {ABCD circle X} (is) not to some area greater than circle {EFGH circle Y}.
And it was shown that neither (is it in that ratio) to (some) lesser (area).
Thus, as the square on {BD line} is to the (square) on {FH line}, so circle {ABCD circle X} (is) to circle {EFGH circle Y}.

Thus, circles are to one another as the squares on (their) diameters.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

Lemma

So, I say that, area {S given} being greater than circle {EFGH circle Y}, as area {S given} is to circle {ABCD circle X}, so circle {EFGH circle Y} (is) to some area less than circle {ABCD circle X}.

For let it have been contrived that as area {S given} (is) to circle {ABCD circle X}, so circle {EFGH circle Y} (is) to area {T given}.
I say that area {T given} is less than circle {ABCD circle X}.
For since as area {S given} is to circle {ABCD circle X}, so circle {EFGH circle Y} (is) to area {T given}, alternately, as area {S given} is to circle {EFGH circle Y}, so circle {ABCD circle X} (is) to area {T given} [Prop. 5.16].
And area {S given} (is) greater than circle {EFGH circle Y}.
Thus, circle {ABCD circle X} (is) also greater than area {T given} [Prop. 5.14].
Hence, as area {S given} is to circle {ABCD circle X}, so circle {EFGH circle Y} (is) to some area less than circle {ABCD circle X}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 3
prose:
Any pyramid having a triangular base is divided into two pyramids having triangular bases (which are) equal, similar to one another, and [similar] to the whole, and into two equal prisms.
And the (sum of the) two prisms is greater than half of the whole pyramid.

Let there be a pyramid whose base is triangle {ABC polygon}, and (whose) apex (is) point {D point}.
I say that pyramid {ABCD given} is divided into two pyramids having triangular bases (which are) equal to one another, and similar to the whole, and into two equal prisms.
And the (sum of the) two prisms is greater than half of the whole pyramid.

For let {AB line}, {BC line}, {CA line}, {AD line}, {DB line}, and {DC line} have been cut in half at points {E point}, {F point}, {G point}, {H point}, {K point}, and {L point} (respectively).
And let {HE line}, {EG line}, {GH line}, {HK line}, {KL line}, {LH line}, {KF line}, and {FG line} have been joined.
Since {AE line} is equal to {EB line}, and {AH line} to {DH line}, {EH line} is thus parallel to {DB line} [Prop. 6.2].
So, for the same (reasons), {HK line} is also parallel to {AB line}.
Thus, {HEBK polygon} is a parallelogram.
Thus, {HK line} is equal to {EB line} [Prop. 1.34].
But, {EB line} is equal to {EA line}.
Thus, {AE line} is also equal to {HK line}.
And {AH line} is also equal to {HD line}.
So the two (straight-lines) {EA line} and {AH line} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {KH line} and {HD line}, respectively.
And angle {EAH angle} (is) equal to angle {KHD angle} [Prop. 1.29].
Thus, base {EH line} is equal to base {KD line} [Prop. 1.4].
Thus, triangle {AEH polygon} is equal and similar to triangle {HKD polygon} [Prop. 1.4].
So, for the same (reasons), triangle {AHG polygon} is also equal and similar to triangle {HLD polygon}.
And since {EH line} and {HG line} are two straight-lines joining one another (which are respectively) parallel to two straight-lines joining one another, {KD line} and {DL line}, not being in the same plane, they will contain equal angles [Prop. 11.10].
Thus, angle {EHG angle} is equal to angle {KDL angle}.
And since the two straight-lines {EH line} and {HG line} are equal to the two straight-lines {KD line} and {DL line}, respectively, and angle {EHG angle} is equal to angle {KDL angle}, base {EG line} [is] thus equal to base {KL line} [Prop. 1.4].
Thus, triangle {EHG polygon} is equal and similar to triangle {KDL polygon}.
So, for the same (reasons), triangle {AEG polygon} is also equal and similar to triangle {HKL polygon}.
Thus, the pyramid whose base is triangle {AEG polygon}, and apex the point {H point}, is equal and similar to the pyramid whose base is triangle {HKL polygon}, and apex the point {D point} [Def. 11.10].
And since {HK line} has been drawn parallel to one of the sides, {AB line}, of triangle {ADB polygon}, triangle {ADB polygon} is equiangular to triangle {DHK polygon} [Prop. 1.29], and they have proportional sides.
Thus, triangle {ADB polygon} is similar to triangle {DHK polygon} [Def. 6.1].
So, for the same (reasons), triangle {DBC polygon} is also similar to triangle {DKL polygon}, and {ADC polygon} to {DLH polygon}.
And since two straight-lines joining one another, {BA line} and {AC line}, are parallel to two straight-lines joining one another, {KH line} and {HL line}, not in the same plane, they will contain equal angles [Prop. 11.10].
Thus, angle {BAC angle} is equal to (angle) {KHL angle}.
And as {BA line} is to {AC line}, so {KH line} (is) to {HL line}.
Thus, triangle {ABC polygon} is similar to triangle {HKL polygon} [Prop. 6.6].
And, thus, the pyramid whose base is triangle {ABC polygon}, and apex the point {D point}, is similar to the pyramid whose base is triangle {HKL polygon}, and apex the point {D point} [Def. 11.9].
But, the pyramid whose base [is] triangle {HKL polygon}, and apex the point {D point}, was shown (to be) similar to the pyramid whose base is triangle {AEG polygon}, and apex the point {H point}.
Thus, each of the pyramids {AEGH given} and {HKLD given} is similar to the whole pyramid {ABCD given}.

And since {BF line} is equal to {FC line}, parallelogram {EBFG polygon} is double triangle {GFC polygon} [Prop. 1.41].
And since, if two prisms (have) equal heights, and the former has a parallelogram as a base, and the latter a triangle, and the parallelogram (is) double the triangle, then the prisms are equal [Prop. 11.39], the prism contained by the two triangles {BKF polygon} and {EHG polygon}, and the three parallelograms {EBFG polygon}, {EBKH polygon}, and {HKFG polygon}, is thus equal to the prism contained by the two triangles {GFC polygon} and {HKL polygon}, and the three parallelograms {KFCL polygon}, {LCGH polygon}, and {HKFG polygon}.
And (it is) clear that each of the prisms whose base (is) parallelogram {EBFG polygon}, and opposite (side) straight-line {HK line}, and whose base (is) triangle {GFC polygon}, and opposite (plane) triangle {HKL polygon}, is greater than each of the pyramids whose bases are triangles {AEG polygon} and {HKL polygon}, and apexes the points {H point} and {D point} (respectively), inasmuch as, if we [also] join the straight-lines {EF line} and {EK line} then the prism whose base (is) parallelogram {EBFG polygon}, and opposite (side) straight-line {HK line}, is greater than the pyramid whose base (is) triangle {EBF polygon}, and apex the point {K point}.
But the pyramid whose base (is) triangle {EBF polygon}, and apex the point {K point}, is equal to the pyramid whose base is triangle {AEG polygon}, and apex point {H point}.
For they are contained by equal and similar planes.
And, hence, the prism whose base (is) parallelogram {EBFG polygon}, and opposite (side) straight-line {HK line}, is greater than the pyramid whose base (is) triangle {AEG polygon}, and apex the point {H point}.
And the prism whose base is parallelogram {EBFG polygon}, and opposite (side) straight-line {HK line}, (is) equal to the prism whose base (is) triangle {GFC polygon}, and opposite (plane) triangle {HKL polygon}.
And the pyramid whose base (is) triangle {AEG polygon}, and apex the point {H point}, is equal to the pyramid whose base (is) triangle {HKL polygon}, and apex the point {D point}.
Thus, the (sum of the) aforementioned two prisms is greater than the (sum of the) aforementioned two pyramids, whose bases (are) triangles {AEG polygon} and {HKL polygon}, and apexes the points {H point} and {D point} (respectively).

Thus, the whole pyramid, whose base (is) triangle {ABC polygon}, and apex the point {D point}, has been divided into two pyramids (which are) equal to one another [and similar to the whole], and into two equal prisms.
And the (sum of the) two prisms is greater than half of the whole pyramid.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 4
prose:
If there are two pyramids with the same height, having trianglular bases, and each of them is divided into two pyramids equal to one another, and similar to the whole, and into two equal prisms then as the base of one pyramid (is) to the base of the other pyramid, so (the sum of) all the prisms in one pyramid will be to (the sum of all) the equal number of prisms in the other pyramid.

Let there be two pyramids with the same height, having the triangular bases {ABC polygon} and {DEF polygon}, (with) apexes the points {G point} and {H point} (respectively).
And let each of them have been divided into two pyramids equal to one another, and similar to the whole, and into two equal prisms [Prop. 12.3].
I say that as base {ABC polygon} is to base {DEF polygon}, so (the sum of) all the prisms in pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to (the sum of) all the equal number of prisms in pyramid {DEFH given}.

For since {BO line} is equal to {OC line}, and {AL line} to {LC line}, {LO line} is thus parallel to {AB line}, and triangle {ABC polygon} similar to triangle {LOC polygon} [Prop. 12.3].
So, for the same (reasons), triangle {DEF polygon} is also similar to triangle {RVF polygon}.
And since {BC line} is double {CO line}, and {EF line} (double) {FV line}, thus as {BC line} (is) to {CO line}, so {EF line} (is) to {FV line}.
And the similar, and similarly laid out, rectilinear (figures) {ABC polygon} and {LOC polygon} have been described on {BC line} and {CO line} (respectively), and the similar, and similarly laid out, [rectilinear] (figures) {DEF polygon} and {RVF polygon} on {EF line} and {FV line} (respectively).
Thus, as triangle {ABC polygon} is to triangle {LOC polygon}, so triangle {DEF polygon} (is) to triangle {RVF polygon} [Prop. 6.22].
Thus, alternately, as triangle {ABC polygon} is to [triangle] {DEF polygon}, so [triangle] {LOC polygon} (is) to triangle {RVF polygon} [Prop. 5.16].
But, as triangle {LOC polygon} (is) to triangle {RVF polygon}, so the prism whose base [is] triangle {LOC polygon}, and opposite (plane) {PMN polygon}, (is) to the prism whose base (is) triangle {RVF polygon}, and opposite (plane) {STU polygon} (see lemma).
And, thus, as triangle {ABC polygon} (is) to triangle {DEF polygon}, so the prism whose base (is) triangle {LOC polygon}, and opposite (plane) {PMN polygon}, (is) to the prism whose base (is) triangle {RVF polygon}, and opposite (plane) {STU polygon}.
And as the aforementioned prisms (are) to one another, so the prism whose base (is) parallelogram {KBOL polygon}, and opposite (side) straight-line {PM line}, (is) to the prism whose base (is) parallelogram {QEVR polygon}, and opposite (side) straight-line {ST line} [Props. 11.39, 12.3].
Thus, also, (is) the (sum of the) two prisms—that whose base (is) parallelogram {KBOL polygon}, and opposite (side) {PM line}, and that whose base (is) {LOC polygon}, and opposite (plane) {PMN polygon}—to (the sum of) the (two) prisms—that whose base (is) {QEVR polygon}, and opposite (side) straight-line {ST line}, and that whose base (is) triangle {RVF polygon}, and opposite (plane) {STU polygon} [Prop. 5.12].
And, thus, as base {ABC polygon} (is) to base {DEF polygon}, so the (sum of the first) aforementioned two prisms (is) to the (sum of the second) aforementioned two prisms.

And, similarly, if pyramids {PMNG given} and {STUH given} are divided into two prisms, and two pyramids, as base {PMN polygon} (is) to base {STU polygon}, so (the sum of) the two prisms in pyramid {PMNG given} will be to (the sum of) the two prisms in pyramid {STUH given}.
But, as base {PMN polygon} (is) to base {STU polygon}, so base {ABC polygon} (is) to base {DEF polygon}.
For the triangles {PMN polygon} and {STU polygon} (are) equal to {LOC polygon} and {RVF polygon}, respectively.
And, thus, as base {ABC polygon} (is) to base {DEF polygon}, so (the sum of) the four prisms (is) to (the sum of) the four prisms [Prop. 5.12].
So, similarly, even if we divide the pyramids left behind into two pyramids and into two prisms, as base {ABC polygon} (is) to base {DEF polygon}, so (the sum of) all the prisms in pyramid {ABCG given} will be to (the sum of) all the equal number of prisms in pyramid {DEFH given}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

Lemma

And one may show, as follows, that as triangle {LOC polygon} is to triangle {RVF polygon}, so the prism whose base (is) triangle {LOC polygon}, and opposite (plane) {PMN polygon}, (is) to the prism whose base (is) [triangle] {RVF polygon}, and opposite (plane) {STU polygon}.

For, in the same figure, let perpendiculars have been conceived (drawn) from (points) {G given} and {H given} to the planes {ABC polygon} and {DEF polygon} (respectively).
These clearly turn out to be equal, on account of the pyramids being assumed (to be) of equal height.
And since two straight-lines, {GC line} and the perpendicular from {G point}, are cut by the parallel planes {ABC polygon} and {PMN polygon} they will be cut in the same ratios [Prop. 11.17].
And {GC line} was cut in half by the plane {PMN polygon} at {N point}.
Thus, the perpendicular from {G point} to the plane {ABC polygon} will also be cut in half by the plane {PMN polygon}.
So, for the same (reasons), the perpendicular from {H point} to the plane {DEF polygon} will also be cut in half by the plane {STU polygon}.
And the perpendiculars from {G point} and {H point} to the planes {ABC polygon} and {DEF polygon} (respectively) are equal.
Thus, the perpendiculars from the triangles {PMN polygon} and {STU polygon} to {ABC polygon} and {DEF polygon} (respectively, are) also equal.
Thus, the prisms whose bases are triangles {LOC polygon} and {RVF polygon}, and opposite (sides) {PMN polygon} and {STU polygon} (respectively), [are] of equal height.
And, hence, the parallelepiped solids described on the aforementioned prisms [are] of equal height and (are) to one another as their bases [Prop. 11.32].
Likewise, the halves (of the solids) [Prop. 11.28].
Thus, as base {LOC polygon} is to base {RVF polygon}, so the aforementioned prisms (are) to one another.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 5
prose:
Pyramids which are of the same height, and have triangular bases, are to one another as their bases.

Let there be pyramids of the same height whose bases (are) the triangles {ABC polygon} and {DEF polygon}, and apexes the points {G point} and {H point} (respectively).
I say that as base {ABC polygon} is to base {DEF polygon}, so pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to pyramid {DEFH given}.

For if base {ABC polygon} is not to base {DEF polygon}, as pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to pyramid {DEFH given}, then base {ABC polygon} will be to base {DEF polygon}, as pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to some solid either less than, or greater than, pyramid {DEFH given}.
Let it, first of all, be (in this ratio) to (some) lesser (solid), {W given}.
And let pyramid {DEFH given} have been divided into two pyramids equal to one another, and similar to the whole, and into two equal prisms.
So, the (sum of the) two prisms is greater than half of the whole pyramid [Prop. 12.3].
And, again, let the pyramids generated by the division have been similarly divided, and let this be done continually until some pyramids are left from pyramid {DEFH given} which (when added together) are less than the excess by which pyramid {DEFH given} exceeds the solid {W given} [Prop. 10.1].
Let them have been left, and, for the sake of argument, let them be {DQRS given} and {STUH given}.
Thus, the (sum of the) remaining prisms within pyramid {DEFH given} is greater than solid {W given}.
Let pyramid {ABCG given} also have been divided similarly, and a similar number of times, as pyramid {DEFH given}.
Thus, as base {ABC polygon} is to base {DEF polygon}, so the (sum of the) prisms within pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to the (sum of the) prisms within pyramid {DEFH given} [Prop. 12.4].
But, also, as base {ABC polygon} (is) to base {DEF polygon}, so pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to solid {W given}.
And, thus, as pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to solid {W given}, so the (sum of the) prisms within pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to the (sum of the) prisms within pyramid {DEFH given} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, alternately, as pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to the (sum of the) prisms within it, so solid {W given} (is) to the (sum of the) prisms within pyramid {DEFH given} [Prop. 5.16].
And pyramid {ABCG given} (is) greater than the (sum of the) prisms within it.
Thus, solid {W given} (is) also greater than the (sum of the) prisms within pyramid {DEFH given} [Prop. 5.14].
But, (it is) also less.
This very thing is impossible.
Thus, as base {ABC polygon} is to base {DEF polygon}, so pyramid {ABCG given} (is) not to some solid less than pyramid {DEFH given}.
So, similarly, we can show that base {DEF polygon} is not to base {ABC polygon}, as pyramid {DEFH given} (is) to some solid less than pyramid {ABCG given} either.

So, I say that neither is base {ABC polygon} to base {DEF polygon}, as pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to some solid greater than pyramid {DEFH given}.

For, if possible, let it be (in this ratio) to some greater (solid), {W given}.
Thus, inversely, as base {DEF polygon} (is) to base {ABC polygon}, so solid {W given} (is) to pyramid {ABCG given} [Prop. 5.7. corr.].
And as solid {W given} (is) to pyramid {ABCG given}, so pyramid {DEFH given} (is) to some (solid) less than pyramid {ABCG given}, as shown before [Prop. 12.2 lem.].
And, thus, as base {DEF polygon} (is) to base {ABC polygon}, so pyramid {DEFH given} (is) to some (solid) less than pyramid {ABCG given} [Prop. 5.11].
The very thing was shown (to be) absurd.
Thus, base {ABC polygon} is not to base {DEF polygon}, as pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to some solid greater than pyramid {DEFH given}.
And, it was shown that neither (is it in this ratio) to a lesser (solid).
Thus, as base {ABC polygon} is to base {DEF polygon}, so pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to pyramid {DEFH given}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 6
prose:
Pyramids which are of the same height, and have polygonal bases, are to one another as their bases.

Let there be pyramids of the same height whose bases (are) the polygons {ABCDE polygon} and {FGHKL polygon}, and apexes the points {M point} and {N point} (respectively).
I say that as base {ABCDE polygon} is to base {FGHKL polygon}, so pyramid {ABCDEM given} (is) to pyramid {FGHKLN given}.

For let {AC line}, {AD line}, {FH line}, and {FK line} have been joined.
Therefore, since {ABCM given} and {ACDM given} are two pyramids having triangular bases and equal height, they are to one another as their bases [Prop. 12.5].
Thus, as base {ABC polygon} is to base {ACD polygon}, so pyramid {ABCM given} (is) to pyramid {ACDM given}.
And, via composition, as base {ABCD polygon} (is) to base {ACD polygon}, so pyramid {ABCDM given} (is) to pyramid {ACDM given} [Prop. 5.18].
But, as base {ACD polygon} (is) to base {ADE polygon}, so pyramid {ACDM given} (is) also to pyramid {ADEM given} [Prop. 12.5].
Thus, via equality, as base {ABCD polygon} (is) to base {ADE polygon}, so pyramid {ABCDM given} (is) to pyramid {ADEM given} [Prop. 5.22].
And, again, via composition, as base {ABCDE polygon} (is) to base {ADE polygon}, so pyramid {ABCDEM given} (is) to pyramid {ADEM given} [Prop. 5.18].
So, similarly, it can also be shown that as base {FGHKL polygon} (is) to base {FGH polygon}, so pyramid {FGHKLN given} (is) also to pyramid {FGHN given}.
And since {ADEM given} and {FGHN given} are two pyramids having triangular bases and equal height, thus as base {ADE polygon} (is) to base {FGH polygon}, so pyramid {ADEM given} (is) to pyramid {FGHN given} [Prop. 12.5].
But, as base {ADE polygon} (is) to base {ABCDE polygon}, so pyramid {ADEM given} (was) to pyramid {ABCDEM given}.
Thus, via equality, as base {ABCDE polygon} (is) to base {FGH polygon}, so pyramid {ABCDEM given} (is) also to pyramid {FGHN given} [Prop. 5.22].
But, furthermore, as base {FGH polygon} (is) to base {FGHKL polygon}, so pyramid {FGHN given} was also to pyramid {FGHKLN given}.
Thus, via equality, as base {ABCDE polygon} (is) to base {FGHKL polygon}, so pyramid {ABCDEM given} (is) also to pyramid {FGHKLN given} [Prop. 5.22].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 7
prose:
Any prism having a triangular base is divided into three pyramids having triangular bases (which are) equal to one another.

Let there be a prism whose base (is) triangle {ABC polygon}, and opposite (plane) {DEF polygon}.
I say that prism {ABCDEF given} is divided into three pyramids having triangular bases (which are) equal to one another.

For let {BD line}, {EC line}, and {CD line} have been joined.
Since {ABED polygon} is a parallelogram, and {BD line} is its diagonal, triangle {ABD polygon} is thus equal to triangle {EBD polygon} [Prop. 1.34].
And, thus, the pyramid whose base (is) triangle {ABD polygon}, and apex the point {C point}, is equal to the pyramid whose base is triangle {DEB polygon}, and apex the point {C point} [Prop. 12.5].
But, the pyramid whose base is triangle {DEB polygon}, and apex the point {C point}, is the same as the pyramid whose base is triangle {EBC polygon}, and apex the point {D point}.
For they are contained by the same planes.
And, thus, the pyramid whose base is {ABD polygon}, and apex the point {C point}, is equal to the pyramid whose base is {EBC polygon} and apex the point {D point}.
Again, since {FCBE polygon} is a parallelogram, and {CE line} is its diagonal, triangle {CEF polygon} is equal to triangle {CBE polygon} [Prop. 1.34].
And, thus, the pyramid whose base is triangle {BCE polygon}, and apex the point {D point}, is equal to the pyramid whose base is triangle {ECF polygon}, and apex the point {D point} [Prop. 12.5].
And the pyramid whose base is triangle {BCE polygon}, and apex the point {D point}, was shown (to be) equal to the pyramid whose base is triangle {ABD polygon}, and apex the point {C point}.
Thus, the pyramid whose base is triangle {CEF polygon}, and apex the point {D point}, is also equal to the pyramid whose base [is] triangle {ABD polygon}, and apex the point {C point}.
Thus, the prism {ABCDEF given} has been divided into three pyramids having triangular bases (which are) equal to one another.

And since the pyramid whose base is triangle {ABD polygon}, and apex the point {C point}, is the same as the pyramid whose base is triangle {CAB polygon}, and apex the point {D point}.
For they are contained by the same planes.
And the pyramid whose base (is) triangle {ABD polygon}, and apex the point {C point}, was shown (to be) a third of the prism whose base is triangle {ABC polygon}, and opposite (plane) {DEF polygon}, thus the pyramid whose base is triangle {ABC polygon}, and apex the point {D point}, is also a third of the pyramid having the same base, triangle {ABC polygon}, and opposite (plane) {DEF polygon}.

Corollary

And, from this, (it is) clear that any pyramid is the third part of the prism having the same base as it, and an equal height.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 8
prose:
Similar pyramids which also have triangular bases are in the cubed ratio of their corresponding sides.

Let there be similar, and similarly laid out, pyramids whose bases are triangles {ABC polygon} and {DEF polygon}, and apexes the points {G point} and {H point} (respectively).
I say that pyramid {ABCG given} has to pyramid {DEFH given} the cubed ratio of that {BC line} (has) to {EF line}.

For let the parallelepiped solids {BGML given} and {EHQP given} have been completed.
And since pyramid {ABCG given} is similar to pyramid {DEFH given}, angle {ABC angle} is thus equal to angle {DEF angle}, and {GBC angle} to {HEF angle}, and {ABG angle} to {DEH angle}.
And as {AB line} is to {DE line}, so {BC line} (is) to {EF line}, and {BG line} to {EH line} [Def.11.9].
And since as {AB line} is to {DE line}, so {BC line} (is) to {EF line}, and (so) the sides around equal angles are proportional, parallelogram {BM polygon} is thus similar to paralleleogram {EQ polygon}.
So, for the same (reasons), {BN polygon} is also similar to {ER polygon}, and {BK polygon} to {EO polygon}.
Thus, the three (parallelograms) {MB polygon}, {BK polygon}, and {BN polygon} are similar to the three (parallelograms) {EQ polygon}, {EO polygon}, {ER polygon} (respectively).
But, the three (parallelograms) {MB polygon}, {BK polygon}, and {BN polygon} are (both) equal and similar to the three opposite (parallelograms), and the three (parallelograms) {EQ polygon}, {EO polygon}, and {ER polygon} are (both) equal and similar to the three opposite (parallelograms) [Prop. 11.24].
Thus, the solids {BGML given} and {EHQP given} are contained by equal numbers of similar (and similarly laid out) planes.
Thus, solid {BGML given} is similar to solid {EHQP given} [Def. 11.9].
And similar parallelepiped solids are in the cubed ratio of corresponding sides [Prop. 11.33].
Thus, solid {BGML given} has to solid {EHQP given} the cubed ratio that the corresponding side {BC line} (has) to the corresponding side {EF line}.
And as solid {BGML given} (is) to solid {EHQP given}, so pyramid {ABCG given} (is) to pyramid {DEFH given}, inasmuch as the pyramid is the sixth part of the solid, on account of the prism, being half of the parallelepiped solid [Prop. 11.28], also being three times the pyramid [Prop. 12.7].
Thus, pyramid {ABCG given} also has to pyramid {DEFH given} the cubed ratio that {BC line} (has) to {EF line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

Corollary

So, from this, (it is) also clear that similar pyramids having polygonal bases (are) to one another as the cubed ratio of their corresponding sides.
For, dividing them into the pyramids (contained) within them which have triangular bases, with the similar polygons of the bases also being divided into similar triangles (which are) both equal in number, and corresponding, to the wholes [Prop. 6.20].
As one pyramid having a triangular base in the former (pyramid having a polygonal base is) to one pyramid having a triangular base in the latter (pyramid having a polygonal base), so (the sum of) all the pyramids having triangular bases in the former pyramid will also be to (the sum of) all the pyramids having triangular bases in the latter pyramid [Prop. 5.12]---that is to say, the (former) pyramid itself having a polygonal base to the (latter) pyramid having a polygonal base.
And a pyramid having a triangular base is to a (pyramid) having a triangular base in the cubed ratio of corresponding sides [Prop. 12.8].
Thus, a (pyramid) having a polygonal base also has to to a (pyramid) having a similar base the cubed ratio of a (corresponding) side to a (corresponding) side.

title: Proposition 9
prose:
The bases of equal pyramids which also have triangular bases are reciprocally proportional to their heights.
And those pyramids which have triangular bases whose bases are reciprocally proportional to their heights are equal.

For let there be (two) equal pyramids having the triangular bases {ABC polygon} and {DEF polygon}, and apexes the points {G point} and {H point} (respectively).
I say that the bases of the pyramids {ABCG given} and {DEFH given} are reciprocally proportional to their heights, and (so) that as base {ABC polygon} is to base {DEF polygon}, so the height of pyramid {DEFH given} (is) to the height of pyramid {ABCG given}.

For let the parallelepiped solids {BGML given} and {EHQP given} have been completed.
And since pyramid {ABCG given} is equal to pyramid {DEFH given}, and solid {BGML given} is six times pyramid {ABCG given} (see previous proposition), and solid {EHQP given} (is) six times pyramid {DEFH given}, solid {BGML given} is thus equal to solid {EHQP given}.
And the bases of equal parallelepiped solids are reciprocally proportional to their heights [Prop. 11.34].
Thus, as base {BM polygon} is to base {EQ polygon}, so the height of solid {EHQP given} (is) to the height of solid {BGML given}.
But, as base {BM polygon} (is) to base {EQ polygon}, so triangle {ABC polygon} (is) to triangle {DEF polygon} [Prop. 1.34].
And, thus, as triangle {ABC polygon} (is) to triangle {DEF polygon}, so the height of solid {EHQP given} (is) to the height of solid {BGML given} [Prop. 5.11].
But, the height of solid {EHQP given} is the same as the height of pyramid {DEFH given}, and the height of solid {BGML given} is the same as the height of pyramid {ABCG given}.
Thus, as base {ABC polygon} is to base {DEF polygon}, so the height of pyramid {DEFH given} (is) to the height of pyramid {ABCG given}.
Thus, the bases of pyramids {ABCG given} and {DEFH given} are reciprocally proportional to their heights.

And so, let the bases of pyramids {ABCG given} and {DEFH given} be reciprocally proportional to their heights, and (thus) let base {ABC polygon} be to base {DEF polygon}, as the height of pyramid {DEFH given} (is) to the height of pyramid {ABCG given}.
I say that pyramid {ABCG given} is equal to pyramid {DEFH given}.

For, with the same construction, since as base {ABC polygon} is to base {DEF polygon}, so the height of pyramid {DEFH given} (is) to the height of pyramid {ABCG given}, but as base {ABC polygon} (is) to base {DEF polygon}, so parallelogram {BM polygon} (is) to parallelogram {EQ polygon} [Prop. 1.34], thus as parallelogram {BM polygon} (is) to parallelogram {EQ polygon}, so the height of pyramid {DEFH given} (is) also to the height of pyramid {ABCG given} [Prop. 5.11].
But, the height of pyramid {DEFH given} is the same as the height of parallelepiped {EHQP given}, and the height of pyramid {ABCG given} is the same as the height of parallelepiped {BGML given}.
Thus, as base {BM polygon} is to base {EQ polygon}, so the height of parallelepiped {EHQP given} (is) to the height of parallelepiped {BGML given}.
And those parallelepiped solids whose bases are reciprocally proportional to their heights are equal [Prop. 11.34].
Thus, the parallelepiped solid {BGML given} is equal to the parallelepiped solid {EHQP given}.
And pyramid {ABCG given} is a sixth part of {BGML given}, and pyramid {DEFH given} a sixth part of parallelepiped {EHQP given}.
Thus, pyramid {ABCG given} is equal to pyramid {DEFH given}.

Thus, the bases of equal pyramids which also have triangular bases are reciprocally proportional to their heights.
And those pyramids having triangular bases whose bases are reciprocally proportional to their heights are equal.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 10
prose:
Every cone is the third part of the cylinder which has the same base as it, and an equal height.

For let there be a cone (with) the same base as a cylinder, (namely) the circle {ABCD circle O}, and an equal height.
I say that the cone is the third part of the cylinder—that is to say, that the cylinder is three times the cone.

For if the cylinder is not three times the cone then the cylinder will be either more than three times, or less than three times, (the cone).
Let it, first of all, be more than three times (the cone).
And let the square {ABCD polygon} have been inscribed in circle {ABCD circle O} [Prop. 4.6].
So, square {ABCD polygon} is more than half of circle {ABCD circle O} [Prop. 12.2].
And let a prism of equal height to the cylinder have been set up on square {ABCD polygon}.
So, the prism set up is more than half of the cylinder, inasmuch as if we also circumscribe a square around circle {ABCD circle O} [Prop. 4.7] then the square inscribed in circle {ABCD circle O} is half of the circumscribed (square).
And the solids set up on them are parallelepiped prisms of equal height.
And parallelepiped solids having the same height are to one another as their bases [Prop. 11.32].
And, thus, the prism set up on square {ABCD polygon} is half of the prism set up on the square circumscribed about circle {ABCD circle O}.
And the cylinder is less than the prism set up on the square circumscribed about circle {ABCD circle O}.
Thus, the prism set up on square {ABCD polygon} of the same height as the cylinder is more than half of the cylinder.
Let the circumferences {AB arcc O}, {BC arcc O}, {CD arcc O}, and {DA arcc O} have been cut in half at points {E point}, {F point}, {G point}, and {H point}.
And let {AE line}, {EB line}, {BF line}, {FC line}, {CG line}, {GD line}, {DH line}, and {HA line} have been joined.
And thus each of the triangles {AEB polygon}, {BFC polygon}, {CGD polygon}, and {DHA polygon} is more than half of the segment of circle {ABCD circle O} about it, as was shown previously [Prop. 12.2].
Let prisms of equal height to the cylinder have been set up on each of the triangles {AEB polygon}, {BFC polygon}, {CGD polygon}, and {DHA polygon}.
And each of the prisms set up is greater than the half part of the segment of the cylinder about it—inasmuch as if we draw (straight-lines) parallel to {AB line}, {BC line}, {CD line}, and {DA line} through points {E point}, {F point}, {G point}, and {H point} (respectively), and complete the parallelograms on {AB line}, {BC line}, {CD line}, and {DA line}, and set up parallelepiped solids of equal height to the cylinder on them, then the prisms on triangles {AEB polygon}, {BFC polygon}, {CGD polygon}, and {DHA polygon} are each half of the set up (parallelepipeds).
And the segments of the cylinder are less than the set up parallelepiped solids.
Hence, the prisms on triangles {AEB polygon}, {BFC polygon}, {CGD polygon}, and {DHA polygon} are also greater than half of the segments of the cylinder about them.
So (if) the remaining circumferences are cut in half, and straight-lines are joined, and prisms of equal height to the cylinder are set up on each of the triangles, and this is done continually, then we will (eventually) leave some segments of the cylinder whose (sum) is less than the excess by which the cylinder exceeds three times the cone [Prop. 10.1].
Let them have been left, and let them be {AE arcc O}, {EB arcc O}, {BF arcc O}, {FC arcc O}, {CG arcc O}, {GD arcc O}, {DH arcc O}, and {HA arcc O}.
Thus, the remaining prism whose base (is) polygon {AEBFCGDH polygon}, and height the same as the cylinder, is greater than three times the cone.
But, the prism whose base is polygon {AEBFCGDH polygon}, and height the same as the cylinder, is three times the pyramid whose base is polygon {AEBFCGDH polygon}, and apex the same as the cone [Prop. 12.7 corr.].
And thus the pyramid whose base [is] polygon {AEBFCGDH polygon}, and apex the same as the cone, is greater than the cone having (as) base circle {ABCD circle O}.
But (it is) also less.
For it is encompassed by it.
The very thing (is) impossible.
Thus, the cylinder is not more than three times the cone.

So, I say that neither (is) the cylinder less than three times the cone.

For, if possible, let the cylinder be less than three times the cone.
Thus, inversely, the cone is greater than the third part of the cylinder.
So, let the square {ABCD polygon} have been inscribed in circle {ABCD circle O} [Prop. 4.6].
Thus, square {ABCD polygon} is greater than half of circle {ABCD circle O}.
And let a pyramid having the same apex as the cone have been set up on square {ABCD polygon}.
Thus, the pyramid set up is greater than the half part of the cone, inasmuch as we showed previously that if we circumscribe a square about the circle [Prop. 4.7] then the square {ABCD polygon} will be half of the square circumscribed about the circle [Prop. 12.2].
And if we set up on the squares parallelepiped solids—which are also called prisms—of the same height as the cone, then the (prism) set up on square {ABCD polygon} will be half of the (prism) set up on the square circumscribed about the circle.
For they are to one another as their bases [Prop. 11.32].
Hence, (the same) also (goes for) the thirds.
Thus, the pyramid whose base is square {ABCD polygon} is half of the pyramid set up on the square circumscribed about the circle [Prop. 12.7 corr.].
And the pyramid set up on the square circumscribed about the circle is greater than the cone.
For it encompasses it.
Thus, the pyramid whose base is square {ABCD polygon}, and apex the same as the cone, is greater than half of the cone.
Let the circumferences {AB arcc O}, {BC arcc O}, {CD arcc O}, and {DA arcc O} have been cut in half at points {E point}, {F point}, {G}, and {H point} (respectively).
And let {AE line}, {EB line}, {BF line}, {FC line}, {CG line}, {GD line}, {DH line}, and {HA line} have been joined.
And, thus, each of the triangles {AEB polygon}, {BFC polygon}, {CGD polygon}, and {DHA polygon} is greater than the half part of the segment of circle {ABCD circle O} about it [Prop. 12.2].
And let pyramids having the same apex as the cone have been set up on each of the triangles {AEB polygon}, {BFC polygon}, {CGD polygon}, and {DHA polygon}.
And, thus, in the same way, each of the pyramids set up is more than the half part of the segment of the cone about it.
So, (if) the remaining circumferences are cut in half, and straightlines are joined, and pyramids having the same apex as the cone are set up on each of the triangles, and this is done continually, then we will (eventually) leave some segments of the cone whose (sum) is less than the excess by which the cone exceeds the third part of the cylinder [Prop. 10.1].
Let them have been left, and let them be the (segments) on {AE arcc O}, {EB arcc O}, {BF arcc O}, {FC arcc O}, {CG arcc O}, {GD arcc O}, {DH arcc O}, and {HA arcc O}.
Thus, the remaining pyramid whose base is polygon {AEBFCGDH polygon}, and apex the same as the cone, is greater than the third part of the cylinder.
But, the pyramid whose base is polygon {AEBFCGDH polygon}, and apex the same as the cone, is the third part of the prism whose base is polygon {AEBFCGDH polygon}, and height the same as the cylinder [Prop. 12.7 corr.].
Thus, the prism whose base is polygon {AEBFCGDH polygon}, and height the same as the cylinder, is greater than the cylinder whose base is circle {ABCD circle O}.
But, (it is) also less.
For it is encompassed by it.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, the cylinder is not less than three times the cone.
And it was shown that neither (is it) greater than three times (the cone).
Thus, the cylinder (is) three times the cone.
Hence, the cone is the third part of the cylinder.

Thus, every cone is the third part of the cylinder which has the same base as it, and an equal height.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 11
prose:
Cones and cylinders having the same height are to one another as their bases.

Let there be cones and cylinders of the same height whose bases [are] the circles {ABCD circle K} and {EFGH circle M}, axes {KL line} and {MN line}, and diameters of the bases {AC line} and {EG line} (respectively).
I say that as circle {ABCD circle K} is to circle {EFGH circle M}, so cone {AL given} (is) to cone {EN given}.

For if not, then as circle {ABCD circle K} (is) to circle {EFGH circle M}, so cone {AL given} will be to some solid either less than, or greater than, cone {EN given}.
Let it, first of all, be (in this ratio) to (some) lesser (solid), {O given}.
And let solid {X given} be equal to that (magnitude) by which solid {O given} is less than cone {EN given}.
Thus, cone {EN given} is equal to (the sum of) solids {O given} and {X given}.
Let the square {EFGH polygon} have been inscribed in circle {EFGH circle M} [Prop. 4.6].
Thus, the square is greater than half of the circle [Prop. 12.2].
Let a pyramid of the same height as the cone have been set up on square {EFGH polygon}.
Thus, the pyramid set up is greater than half of the cone, inasmuch as, if we circumscribe a square about the circle [Prop. 4.7], and set up on it a pyramid of the same height as the cone, then the inscribed pyramid is half of the circumscribed pyramid.
For they are to one another as their bases [Prop. 12.6].
And the cone (is) less than the circumscribed pyramid.
Let the circumferences {EF arcc M}, {FG arcc M}, {GH arcc M}, and {HE arcc M} have been cut in half at points {P point}, {Q point}, {R point}, and {S point}.
And let {HP line}, {PE line}, {EQ line}, {QF line}, {FR line}, {RG line}, {GS line}, and {SH line} have been joined.
Thus, each of the triangles {HPE polygon}, {EQF polygon}, {FRG polygon}, and {GSH polygon} is greater than half of the segment of the circle about it [Prop. 12.2].
Let pyramids of the same height as the cone have been set up on each of the triangles {HPE polygon}, {EQF polygon}, {FRG polygon}, and {GSH polygon}.
And, thus, each of the pyramids set up is greater than half of the segment of the cone about it [Prop. 12.10].
So, (if) the remaining circumferences are cut in half, and straight-lines are joined, and pyramids of equal height to the cone are set up on each of the triangles, and this is done continually, then we will (eventually) leave some segments of the cone (the sum of) which is less than solid {X given} [Prop. 10.1].
Let them have been left, and let them be the (segments) on {HPE arcc M}, {EQF arcc M}, {FRG arcc M}, and {GSH arcc M}.
Thus, the remaining pyramid whose base is polygon {HPEQFRGS polygon}, and height the same as the cone, is greater than solid {O point} [Prop. 6.18].
And let the polygon {DTAUBVCW polygon}, similar, and similarly laid out, to polygon {HPEQFRGS polygon}, have been inscribed in circle {ABCD circle K}.
And on it let a pyramid of the same height as cone {AL given} have been set up.
Therefore, since as the (square) on {AC line} is to the (square) on {EG line}, so polygon {DTAUBVCW polygon} (is) to polygon {HPEQFRGS polygon} [Prop. 12.1], and as the (square) on {AC line} (is) to the (square) on {EG line}, so circle {ABCD circle K} (is) to circle {EFGH circle M} [Prop. 12.2], thus as circle {ABCD circle K} (is) to circle {EFGH circle M}, so polygon {DTAUBVCW polygon} also (is) to polygon {HPEQFRGS polygon}.
And as circle {ABCD circle K} (is) to circle {EFGH circle M}, so cone {AL given} (is) to solid {O given}.
And as polygon {DTAUBVCW polygon} (is) to polygon {HPEQFRGS polygon}, so the pyramid whose base is polygon {DTAUBVCW polygon}, and apex the point {L point}, (is) to the pyramid whose base is polygon {HPEQFRGS polygon}, and apex the point {N point} [Prop. 12.6].
And, thus, as cone {AL given} (is) to solid {O given}, so the pyramid whose base is {DTAUBVCW polygon}, and apex the point {L point}, (is) to the pyramid whose base is polygon {HPEQFRGS polygon}, and apex the point {N point} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, alternately, as cone {AL given} is to the pyramid within it, so solid {O given} (is) to the pyramid within cone {EN given} [Prop. 5.16].
But, cone {AL given} (is) greater than the pyramid within it.
Thus, solid {O given} (is) also greater than the pyramid within cone {EN given} [Prop. 5.14].
But, (it is) also less.
The very thing (is) absurd.
Thus, circle {ABCD circle K} is not to circle {EFGH circle M}, as cone {AL given} (is) to some solid less than cone {EN given}.
So, similarly, we can show that neither is circle {EFGH circle M} to circle {ABCD circle K}, as cone {EN given} (is) to some solid less than cone {AL given}.

So, I say that neither is circle {ABCD circle K} to circle {EFGH circle M}, as cone {AL given} (is) to some solid greater than cone {EN given}.

For, if possible, let it be (in this ratio) to (some) greater (solid), {O given}.
Thus, inversely, as circle {EFGH circle M} is to circle {ABCD circle K}, so solid {O given} (is) to cone {AL given} [Prop. 5.7 corr.].
But, as solid {O given} (is) to cone {AL given}, so cone {EN given} (is) to some solid less than cone {AL given} [Prop. 12.2 lem.].
And, thus, as circle {EFGH circle M} (is) to circle {ABCD circle K}, so cone {EN given} (is) to some solid less than cone {AL given}.
The very thing was shown (to be) impossible.
Thus, circle {ABCD circle K} is not to circle {EFGH circle M}, as cone {AL given} (is) to some solid greater than cone {EN given}.
And, it was shown that neither (is it in this ratio) to (some) lesser (solid).
Thus, as circle {ABCD circle K} is to circle {EFGH circle M}, so cone {AL given} (is) to cone {EN given}.

But, as the cone (is) to the cone, (so) the cylinder (is) to the cylinder.
For each (is) three times each [Prop. 12.10].
Thus, circle {ABCD circle K} (is) also to circle {EFGH circle M}, as (the ratio of the cylinders) on them (having) the same height.

Thus, cones and cylinders having the same height are to one another as their bases.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 12
prose:
Similar cones and cylinders are to one another in the cubed ratio of the diameters of their bases.

Let there be similar cones and cylinders of which the bases (are) the circles {ABCD circle K} and {EFGH circle M}, the diameters of the bases (are) {BD line} and {FH line}, and the axes of the cones and cylinders (are) {KL line} and {MN line} (respectively).
I say that the cone whose base [is] circle {ABCD circle K}, and apex the point {L point}, has to the cone whose base [is] circle {EFGH circle M}, and apex the point {N point}, the cubed ratio that {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.

For if cone {ABCDL given} does not have to cone {EFGHN given} the cubed ratio that {BD line} (has) to {FH line} then cone {ABCDL given} will have the cubed ratio to some solid either less than, or greater than, cone {EFGHN given}.
Let it, first of all, have (such a ratio) to (some) lesser (solid), {O given}.
And let the square {EFGH polygon} have been inscribed in circle {EFGH circle M} [Prop. 4.6].
Thus, square {EFGH polygon} is greater than half of circle {EFGH circle M} [Prop. 12.2].
And let a pyramid having the same apex as the cone have been set up on square {EFGH polygon}.
Thus, the pyramid set up is greater than the half part of the cone [Prop. 12.10].
So, let the circumferences {EF arc M}, {FG arc M}, {GH arc M}, and {HE arc M} have been cut in half at points {P point}, {Q point}, {R point}, and {S point} (respectively).
And let {EP line}, {PF line}, {FQ line}, {QG line}, {GR line}, {RH line}, {HS line}, and {SE line} have been joined.
And, thus, each of the triangles {EPF polygon}, {FQG polygon}, {GRH polygon}, and {HSE polygon} is greater than the half part of the segment of circle {EFGH circle M} about it [Prop. 12.2].
And let a pyramid having the same apex as the cone have been set up on each of the triangles {EPF polygon}, {FQG polygon}, {GRH polygon}, and {HSE polygon}.
And thus each of the pyramids set up is greater than the half part of the segment of the cone about it [Prop. 12.10].
So, (if) the the remaining circumferences are cut in half, and straight-lines are joined, and pyramids having the same apex as the cone are set up on each of the triangles, and this is done continually, then we will (eventually) leave some segments of the cone whose (sum) is less than the excess by which cone {EFGHN given} exceeds solid {O given} [Prop. 10.1].
Let them have been left, and let them be the (segments) on {EP arc M}, {PF arc M}, {FQ arc M}, {QG arc M}, {GR arc M}, {RH arc M}, {HS arc M}, and {SE arc M}.
Thus, the remaining pyramid whose base is polygon {EPFQGRHS polygon}, and apex the point {N point}, is greater than solid {O given}.
And let the polygon {ATBUCVDW polygon}, similar, and similarly laid out, to polygon {EPFQGRHS polygon}, have been inscribed in circle {ABCD circle K} [Prop. 6.18].
And let a pyramid having the same apex as the cone have been set up on polygon {ATBUCVDW polygon}.
And let {LBT polygon} be one of the triangles containing the pyramid whose base is polygon {ATBUCVDW polygon}, and apex the point {L point}.
And let {NFP polygon} be one of the triangles containing the pyramid whose base is triangle {EPFQGRHS polygon}, and apex the point {N point}.
And let {KT line} and {MP line} have been joined.
And since cone {ABCDL given} is similar to cone {EFGHN given}, thus as {BD line} is to {FH line}, so axis {KL line} (is) to axis {MN line} [Def. 11.24].
And as {BD line} (is) to {FH line}, so {BK line} (is) to {FM line}.
And, thus, as {BK line} (is) to {FM line}, so {KL line} (is) to {MN line}.
And, alternately,as {BK line} (is) to {KL line}, so {FM line} (is) to {MN line} [Prop. 5.16].
And the sides around the equal angles {BKL angle} and {FMN angle} are proportional.
Thus, triangle {BKL polygon} is similar to triangle {FMN polygon} [Prop. 6.6].
Again, since as {BK line} (is) to {KT line}, so {FM line} (is) to {MP line}, and (they are) about the equal angles {BKT angle} and {FMP angle}, inasmuch as whatever part angle {BKT angle} is of the four right-angles at the center {K point}, angle {FMP angle} is also the same part of the four right-angles at the center {M point}.
Therefore, since the sides about equal angles are proportional, triangle {BKT polygon} is thus similar to traingle {FMP polygon} [Prop. 6.6].
Again, since it was shown that as {BK line} (is) to {KL line}, so {FM line} (is) to {MN line}, and {BK line} (is) equal to {KT line}, and {FM line} to {PM line}, thus as {TK line} (is) to {KL line}, so {PM line} (is) to {MN line}.
And the sides about the equal angles {TKL angle} and {PMN angle} ---for (they are both) right-angles---are proportional.
Thus, triangle {LKT angle} (is) similar to triangle {NMP angle} [Prop. 6.6].
And since, on account of the similarity of triangles {LKB polygon} and {NMF polygon}, as {LB line} (is) to {BK line}, so {NF line} (is) to {FM line}, and, on account of the similarity of triangles {BKT polygon} and {FMP polygon}, as {KB line} (is) to {BT line}, so {MF line} (is) to {FP line} [Def. 6.1], thus, via equality, as {LB line} (is) to {BT line}, so {NF line} (is) to {FP line} [Prop. 5.22].
Again, since, on account of the similarity of triangles {LTK polygon} and {NPM polygon}, as {LT line} (is) to {TK line}, so {NP line} (is) to {PM line}, and, on account of the similarity of triangles {TKB polygon} and {PMF polygon}, as {KT line} (is) to {TB line}, so {MP line} (is) to {PF line}, thus, via equality, as {LT line} (is) to {TB line}, so {NP line} (is) to {PF line} [Prop. 5.22].
And it was shown that as {TB line} (is) to {BL line}, so {PF line} (is) to {FN line}.
Thus, via equality, as {TL line} (is) to {LB line}, so {PN line} (is) to {NF line} [Prop. 5.22].
Thus, the sides of triangles {LTB polygon} and {NPF polygon} are proportional.
Thus, triangles {LTB polygon} and {NPF polygon} are equiangular [Prop. 6.5].
And, hence, (they are) similar [Def. 6.1].
And, thus, the pyramid whose base is triangle {BKT polygon}, and apex the point {L point}, is similar to the pyramid whose base is triangle {FMP polygon}, and apex the point {N point}.
For they are contained by equal numbers of similar planes [Def. 11.9].
And similar pyramids which also have triangular bases are in the cubed ratio of corresponding sides [Prop. 12.8].
Thus, pyramid {BKTL given} has to pyramid {FMPN given} the cubed ratio that {BK line} (has) to {FM line}.
So, similarly, joining straight-lines from (points) {A point}, {W point}, {D point}, {V point}, {C point}, and {U point} to (center) {K point}, and from (points) {E point}, {S point}, {H point}, {R point}, {G point}, and {Q point} to (center) {M point}, and setting up pyramids having the same apexes as the cones on each of the triangles (so formed), we can also show that each of the pyramids (on base {ABCD polygon} taken) in order will have to each of the pyramids (on base {EFGH polygon} taken) in order the cubed ratio that the corresponding side {BK line} (has) to the corresponding side {FM line} —that is to say, that {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.
And (for two sets of proportional magnitudes) as one of the leading (magnitudes is) to one of the following, so (the sum of) all of the leading (magnitudes is) to (the sum of) all of the following (magnitudes) [Prop. 5.12].
And, thus, as pyramid {BKTL given} (is) to pyramid {FMPN given}, so the whole pyramid whose base is polygon {ATBUCVDW polygon}, and apex the point {L point}, (is) to the whole pyramid whose base is polygon {EPFQGRHS polygon}, and apex the point {N point}.
And, hence, the pyramid whose base is polygon {ATBUCVDW polygon}, and apex the point {L point}, has to the pyramid whose base is polygon {EPFQGRHS polygon}, and apex the point {N point}, the cubed ratio that {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.
And it was also assumed that the cone whose base is circle {ABCD circle K}, and apex the point {L point}, has to solid {O given} the cubed ratio that {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.
Thus, as the cone whose base is circle {ABCD circle K}, and apex the point {L point}, is to solid {O given}, so the pyramid whose base (is) [polygon] {ATBUCVDW polygon}, and apex the point {L point}, (is) to the pyramid whose base is polygon {EPFQGRHS polygon}, and apex the point {N point}.
Thus, alternately, as the cone whose base (is) circle {ABCD circle K}, and apex the point {L point}, (is) to the pyramid within it whose base (is) the polygon {ATBUCVDW polygon}, and apex the point {L point}, so the [solid] {O given} (is) to the pyramid whose base is polygon {EPFQGRHS polygon}, and apex the point {N point} [Prop. 5.16].
And the aforementioned cone (is) greater than the pyramid within it.
For it encompasses it.
Thus, solid {O given} (is) also greater than the pyramid whose base is polygon {EPFQGRHS polygon}, and apex the point {N point}.
But, (it is) also less.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, the cone whose base (is) circle {ABCD circle K}, and apex the [point] {L point}, does not have to some solid less than the cone whose base (is) circle {EFGH circle M}, and apex the point {N point}, the cubed ratio that {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.
So, similarly, we can show that neither does cone {EFGHN given} have to some solid less than cone {ABCDL given} the cubed ratio that {FH line} (has) to {BD line}.

So, I say that neither does cone {ABCDL given} have to some solid greater than cone {EFGHN given} the cubed ratio that {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.

For, if possible, let it have (such a ratio) to a greater (solid), {O given}.
Thus, inversely, solid {O given} has to cone {ABCDL given} the cubed ratio that {FH line} (has) to {BD line} [Prop. 5.7 corr.].
And as solid {O given} (is) to cone {ABCDL given}, so cone {EFGHN given} (is) to some solid less than cone {ABCDL given} [12.2 lem.].
Thus, cone {EFGHN given} also has to some solid less than cone {ABCDL given} the cubed ratio that {FH line} (has) to {BD line}.
The very thing was shown (to be) impossible.
Thus, cone {ABCDL given} does not have to some solid greater than cone {EFGHN given} the cubed ratio than {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.
And it was shown that neither (does it have such a ratio) to a lesser (solid).
Thus, cone {ABCDL given} has to cone {EFGHN given} the cubed ratio that {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.

And as the cone (is) to the cone, so the cylinder (is) to the cylinder.
For a cylinder is three times a cone on the same base as the cone, and of the same height as it [Prop. 12.10].
Thus, the cylinder also has to the cylinder the cubed ratio that {BD line} (has) to {FH line}.

Thus, similar cones and cylinders are in the cubed ratio of the diameters of their bases.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 13
prose:
If a cylinder is cut by a plane which is parallel to the opposite planes (of the cylinder) then as the cylinder (is) to the cylinder, so the axis will be to the axis.

For let the cylinder {AD given} have been cut by the plane {GH given} which is parallel to the opposite planes (of the cylinder), {AB given} and {CD given}.
And let the plane {GH given} have met the axis at point {K point}.
I say that as cylinder {BG given} is to cylinder {GD given}, so axis {EK line} (is) to axis {KF line}.

For let axis {EF line} have been produced in each direction to points {L point} and {M point}.
And let any number whatsoever (of lengths), {EN line} and {NL line}, equal to axis {EK line}, be set out (on the axis {EL line}), and any number whatsoever (of lengths), {FO line} and {OM line}, equal to (axis) {FK line}, (on the axis {KM line}).
And let the cylinder {PW given}, whose bases (are) the circles {PQ given} and {VW given}, have been conceived on axis {LM line}.
And let planes parallel to {AB given}, {CD given}, and the bases of cylinder {PW given}, have been produced through points {N point} and {O point}, and let them have made the circles {RS given} and {TU given} around the centers {N point} and {O point} (respectively).
And since axes {LN line}, {NE line}, and {EK line} are equal to one another, the cylinders {QR given}, {RB given}, and {BG given} are to one another as their bases [Prop. 12.11].
But the bases are equal.
Thus, the cylinders {QR given}, {RB given}, and {BG given} (are) also equal to one another.
Therefore, since the axes {LN line}, {NE line}, and {EK line} are equal to one another, and the cylinders {QR given}, {RB given}, and {BG given} are also equal to one another, and the number (of the former) is equal to the number (of the latter), thus as many multiples as axis {KL line} is of axis {EK line}, so many multiples is cylinder {QG given} also of cylinder {GB given}.
And so, for the same (reasons), as many multiples as axis {MK line} is of axis {KF line}, so many multiples is cylinder {WG given} also of cylinder {GD given}.
And if axis {KL line} is equal to axis {KM line} then cylinder {QG given} will also be equal to cylinder {GW given}, and if the axis (is) greater than the axis then the cylinder (will also be) greater than the cylinder, and if (the axis is) less then (the cylinder will also be) less.
So, there are four magnitudes—the axes {EK line} and {KF line}, and the cylinders {BG given} and {GD given}—and equal multiples have been taken of axis {EK line} and cylinder {BG given}—(namely), axis {LK line} and cylinder {QG given}—and of axis {KF line} and cylinder {GD given}—(namely), axis {KM line} and cylinder {GW given}.
And it has been shown that if axis {KL line} exceeds axis {KM line} then cylinder {QG given} also exceeds cylinder {GW given}, and if (the axes are) equal then (the cylinders are) equal, and if ({KL line} is) less then ({QG given} is) less.
Thus, as axis {EK line} is to axis {KF line}, so cylinder {BG given} (is) to cylinder {GD given} [Def. 5.5].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 14
prose:
Cones and cylinders which are on equal bases are to one another as their heights.

For let {EB given} and {FD given} be cylinders on equal bases, (namely) the circles {AB given} and {CD given} (respectively).
I say that as cylinder {EB given} is to cylinder {FD given}, so axis {GH line} (is) to axis {KL line}.

For let the axis {KL line} have been produced to point {N point}.
And let {LN line} be made equal to axis {GH line}.
And let the cylinder {CM given} have been conceived about axis {LN line}.
Therefore, since cylinders {EB given} and {CM given} have the same height they are to one another as their bases [Prop. 12.11].
And the bases are equal to one another.
Thus, cylinders {EB given} and {CM given} are also equal to one another.
And since cylinder {FM given} has been cut by the plane {CD given}, which is parallel to its opposite planes, thus as cylinder {CM given} is to cylinder {FD given}, so axis {LN line} (is) to axis {KL line} [Prop. 12.13].
And cylinder {CM given} is equal to cylinder {EB given}, and axis {LN line} to axis {GH line}.
Thus, as cylinder {EB given} is to cylinder {FD given}, so axis {GH line} (is) to axis {KL line}.
And as cylinder {EB given} (is) to cylinder {FD given}, so cone {ABG given} (is) to cone {CDK given} [Prop. 12.10].
Thus, also, as axis {GH line} (is) to axis {KL line}, so cone {ABG given} (is) to cone {CDK given}, and cylinder {EB given} to cylinder {FD given}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 15
prose:
The bases of equal cones and cylinders are reciprocally proportional to their heights.
And, those cones and cylinders whose bases (are) reciprocally proportional to their heights are equal.

Let there be equal cones and cylinders whose bases are the circles {ABCD given} and {EFGH given}, and the diameters of (the bases) {AC line} and {EG line}, and (whose) axes (are) {KL line} and {MN line}, which are also the heights of the cones and cylinders (respectively).
And let the cylinders {AO given} and {EP given} have been completed.
I say that the bases of cylinders {AO given} and {EP given} are reciprocally proportional to their heights, and (so) as base {ABCD given} is to base {EFGH given}, so height {MN line} (is) to height {KL line}.

For height {LK line} is either equal to height {MN line}, or not.
Let it, first of all, be equal.
And cylinder {AO given} is also equal to cylinder {EP given}.
And cones and cylinders having the same height are to one another as their bases [Prop. 12.11].
Thus, base {ABCD given} (is) also equal to base {EFGH given}.
And, hence, reciprocally, as base {ABCD given} (is) to base {EFGH given}, so height {MN line} (is) to height {KL line}.
And so, let height {LK line} not be equal to {MN line}, but let {MN line} be greater.
And let {QN line}, equal to {KL line}, have been cut off from height {MN line}.
And let the cylinder {EP given} have been cut, through point {Q point}, by the plane {TUS given} (which is) parallel to the planes of the circles {EFGH given} and {RP given}.
And let cylinder {ES given} have been conceived, with base the circle {EFGH given}, and height {NQ line}.
And since cylinder {AO given} is equal to cylinder {EP given}, thus, as cylinder {AO given} (is) to cylinder {ES given}, so cylinder {EP given} (is) to cylinder {ES given} [Prop. 5.7].
But, as cylinder {AO given} (is) to cylinder {ES given}, so base {ABCD given} (is) to base {EFGH given}.
For cylinders {AO given} and {ES given} (have) the same height [Prop. 12.11].
And as cylinder {EP given} (is) to (cylinder) {ES given}, so height {MN line} (is) to height {QN line}.
For cylinder {EP given} has been cut by a plane which is parallel to its opposite planes [Prop. 12.13].
And, thus, as base {ABCD given} is to base {EFGH given}, so height {MN line} (is) to height {QN line} [Prop. 5.11].
And height {QN line} (is) equal to height {KL line}.
Thus, as base {ABCD given} is to base {EFGH given}, so height {MN line} (is) to height {KL line}.
Thus, the bases of cylinders {AO given} and {EP given} are reciprocally proportional to their heights.

And, so, let the bases of cylinders {AO given} and {EP given} be reciprocally proportional to their heights, and (thus) let base {ABCD given} be to base {EFGH given}, as height {MN line} (is) to height {KL line}.
I say that cylinder {AO given} is equal to cylinder {EP given}.

For, with the same construction, since as base {ABCD given} is to base {EFGH given}, so height {MN line} (is) to height {KL line}, and height {KL line} (is) equal to height {QN line}, thus, as base {ABCD given} (is) to base {EFGH given}, so height {MN line} will be to height {QN line}.
But, as base {ABCD given} (is) to base {EFGH given}, so cylinder {AO given} (is) to cylinder {ES given}.
For they are the same height [Prop. 12.11].
And as height {MN line} (is) to [height] {QN line}, so cylinder {EP given} (is) to cylinder {ES given} [Prop. 12.13].
Thus, as cylinder {AO given} is to cylinder {ES given}, so cylinder {EP given} (is) to (cylinder) {ES given} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, cylinder {AO given} (is) equal to cylinder {EP given} [Prop. 5.9].
In the same manner, (the proposition can) also (be demonstrated) for the cones.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 16
prose:
There being two circles about the same center, to inscribe an equilateral and even-sided polygon in the greater circle, not touching the lesser circle.

Let {ABCD circle K} and {EFGH circle K} be the given two circles, about the same center, {K point}.
So, it is necessary to inscribe an equilateral and even-sided polygon in the greater circle {ABCD circle K}, not touching circle {EFGH circle K}.

Let the straight-line {BKD line} have been drawn through the center {K point}.
And let {GA line} have been drawn, at right-angles to the straight-line {BD line}, through point {G point}, and let it have been drawn through to {C point}.
Thus, {AC line} touches circle {EFGH circle K} [Prop. 3.16 corr.].
So, (by) cutting circumference {BAD arc K} in half, and the half of it in half, and doing this continually, we will (eventually) leave a circumference less than {AD arc K} [Prop. 10.1].
Let it have been left, and let it be {LD arc K}.
And let {LM line} have been drawn, from {L point}, perpendicular to {BD line}, and let it have been drawn through to {N point}.
And let {LD line} and {DN line} have been joined.
Thus, {LD line} is equal to {DN line} [Props. 3.3, 1.4].
And since {LN line} is parallel to {AC line} [Prop. 1.28], and {AC line} touches circle {EFGH circle K}, {LN line} thus does not touch circle {EFGH circle K}.
Thus, even more so, {LD line} and {DN line} do not touch circle {EFGH circle K}.
And if we continuously insert (straight-lines) equal to straight-line {LD line} into circle {ABCD circle K} [Prop. 4.1] then an equilateral and even-sided polygon, not touching the lesser circle {EFGH circle K}, will have been inscribed in circle {ABCD circle K}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to do.

title: Proposition 17
prose:
There being two spheres about the same center, to inscribe a polyhedral solid in the greater sphere, not touching the lesser sphere on its surface.

Let two spheres have been conceived about the same center, {A point}.
So, it is necessary to inscribe a polyhedral solid in the greater sphere, not touching the lesser sphere on its surface.

Let the spheres have been cut by some plane through the center.
So, the sections will be circles, inasmuch as a sphere is generated by the diameter remaining behind, and a semi-circle being carried around [Def. 11.14].
And, hence, whatever position we conceive (of for) the semi-circle, the plane produced through it will make a circle on the surface of the sphere.
And (it is) clear that (it is) also a great (circle), inasmuch as the diameter of the sphere, which is also manifestly the diameter of the semi-circle and the circle, is greater than all of the (other) [straight-lines] drawn across in the circle or the sphere [Prop. 3.15].
Therefore, let {BCDE given} be the circle in the greater sphere, and {FGH given} the circle in the lesser sphere.
And let two diameters of them have been drawn at right-angles to one another, (namely), {BD line} and {CE line}.
And there being two circles about the same center—(namely), {BCDE given} and {FGH given}—let an equilateral and even-sided polygon have been inscribed in the greater circle, {BCDE given}, not touching the lesser circle, {FGH given} [Prop. 12.16], of which let the sides in the quadrant {BE given} be {BK line}, {KL line}, {LM line}, and {ME line}.
And, {KA line} being joined, let it have been drawn across to {N point}.
And let {AO line} have been set up at point {A point}, at right-angles to the plane of circle {BCDE given}.
And let it meet the surface of the (greater) sphere at {O point}.
And let planes have been produced through {AO line} and each of {BD line} and {KN line}.
So, according to the aforementioned (discussion), they will make great circles on the surface of the (greater) sphere.
Let them make (great circles), of which let {BOD given} and {KON given} be semi-circles on the diameters {BD line} and {KN line} (respectively).
And since {OA line} is at right-angles to the plane of circle {BCDE given}, all of the planes through {OA line} are thus also at right-angles to the plane of circle {BCDE given} [Prop. 11.18].
And, hence, the semi-circles {BOD given} and {KON given} are also at right-angles to the plane of circle {BCDE given}.
And since semi-circles {BED given}, {BOD given}, and {KON given} are equal—for (they are) on the equal diameters {BD line} and {KN line} [Def. 3.1]—the quadrants {BE given}, {BO given}, and {KO given} are also equal to one another.
Thus, as many sides of the polygon as are in quadrant {BE given}, so many are also in quadrants {BO given} and {KO given} equal to the straight-lines {BK line}, {KL line}, {LM line}, and {ME line}.
Let them have been inscribed, and let them be {BP line}, {PQ line}, {QR line}, {RO line}, {KS line}, {ST line}, {TU line}, and {UO line}.
And let {SP line}, {TQ line}, and {UR line} have been joined.
And let perpendiculars have been drawn from {P point} and {S point} to the plane of circle {BCDE given} [Prop. 11.11].
So, they will fall on the common sections of the planes {BD line} and {KN line} (with {BCDE given}), inasmuch as the planes of {BOD given} and {KON given} are also at right-angles to the plane of circle {BCDE given} [Def. 11.4].
Let them have fallen, and let them be {PV line} and {SW line}.
And let {WV line} have been joined.
And since {BP given} and {KS given} are equal (circumferences) having been cut off in the equal semi-circles {BOD given} and {KON given} [Def. 3.28], and {PV line} and {SW line} are perpendiculars having been drawn (from them), {PV line} is [thus] equal to {SW line}, and {BV line} to {KW line} [Props. 3.27, 1.26].
And the whole of {BA line} is also equal to the whole of {KA line}.
And, thus, as {BV line} is to {VA line}, so {KW line} (is) to {WA line}.
{WV line} is thus parallel to {KB line} [Prop. 6.2].
And since {PV line} and {SW line} are each at right-angles to the plane of circle {BCDE given}, {PV line} is thus parallel to {SW line} [Prop. 11.6].
And it was also shown (to be) equal to it.
And, thus, {WV line} and {SP line} are equal and parallel [Prop. 1.33].
And since {WV line} is parallel to {SP line}, but {WV line} is parallel to {KB line}, {SP line} is thus also parallel to {KB line} [Prop. 11.1].
And {BP line} and {KS line} join them.
Thus, the quadrilateral {KBPS polygon} is in one plane, inasmuch as if there are two parallel straight-lines, and a random point is taken on each of them, then the straight-line joining the points is in the same plane as the parallel (straight-lines) [Prop. 11.7].
So, for the same (reasons), each of the quadrilaterals {SPQT polygon} and {TQRU polygon} is also in one plane.
And triangle {URO polygon} is also in one plane [Prop. 11.2].
So, if we conceive straight-lines joining points {P point}, {S point}, {Q point}, {T point}, {R point}, and {U point} to {A point} then some solid polyhedral figure will have been constructed between the circumferences {BO given} and {KO given}, being composed of pyramids whose bases (are) the quadrilaterals {KBPS polygon}, {SPQT polygon}, {TQRU polygon}, and the triangle {URO polygon}, and apex the point {A point}.
And if we also make the same construction on each of the sides {KL line}, {LM line}, and {ME line}, just as on {BK line}, and, further, (repeat the construction) in the remaining three quadrants, then some polyhedral figure which has been inscribed in the sphere will have been constructed, being contained by pyramids whose bases (are) the aforementioned quadrilaterals, and triangle {URO polygon}, and the (quadrilaterals and triangles) similarly arranged to them, and apex the point {A point}.

So, I say that the aforementioned polyhedron will not touch the lesser sphere on the surface on which the circle {FGH given} is (situated).

Let the perpendicular (straight-line) {AX line} have been drawn from point {A point} to the plane {KBPS polygon}, and let it meet the plane at point {X point} [Prop. 11.11].
And let {XB line} and {XK line} have been joined.
And since {AX line} is at right-angles to the plane of quadrilateral {KBPS polygon}, it is thus also at right-angles to all of the straight-lines joined to it which are also in the plane of the quadrilateral [Def. 11.3].
Thus, {AX line} is at right-angles to each of {BX line} and {XK line}.
And since {AB line} is equal to {AK line}, the (square) on {AB line} is also equal to the (square) on {AK line}.
And the (sum of the squares) on {AX line} and {XB line} is equal to the (square) on {AB line}.
For the angle at {X point} (is) a right-angle [Prop. 1.47].
